title: Jim O'Neill takes control at flexible office start-up Second Home
text:
Former Goldman Sachs chief economist and ex-Treasury minister Lord Jim O'Neill has become the controlling shareholder of Second Home, the flexible office provider hoping to take advantage of a surge of interest after the pandemic.

The House of Lords peer has taken a stake of about 35 per cent in the business, which was founded by a former adviser to ex-British prime minister David Cameron. The change of controlling shareholding was revealed in Companies House filings on Tuesday.

O'Neill confirmed his increased stake in Second Home when contacted by the Financial Times, and said he would also support the growth of the business with a “modest” cash injection.

“Its got very big potential,” he said. “The growth of flexible offices will be one of the major consequences of the pandemic and I hope to help grow it in a sensible way.”

The move follows a period of turmoil at the start-up, which has struggled to open new sites and was forced to seek funding in 2019 after heavy cost overruns on its space in Los Angeles. The Covid-19 pandemic has added it to its woes as potential customers have worked from home.

O'Neill, a former economist and government minister who coined the acronym Brics for Brazil, Russia, Indian and China, has been a shareholder in the business since it was launched.

He has acquired the extra shares from Gerard Chan, the real estate investor, according to a person familiar with the matter. O'Neill will put one of his team on the board as chair of the group. 

Second Home opened its first site in east London in 2014. It now has three other buildings in London, another in Lisbon and its Los Angeles site.

Its co-founder, Rohan Silva, who was a tech and start-up policy adviser for Cameron, will remain as chief executive. Silva was not available for comment.

The valuation at which O'Neill bought the shares was unclear. Pembroke VCT, another of Second Home's investors, currently values the start-up at £26m, far below the £130m it marked the company at in early 2019.

Pembroke had already taken a writedown on its investment before the pandemic, with results released in December 2019 stating that Second Home was among its investments whose “performance has fallen short of our expectations”.

The firm has also taken money from the government's Future Fund, according to a person familiar with the matter. This offered convertible loans to start-ups that needed funds during the pandemic, which could then become equity stakes for the government after the next fundraising.

Second Home's other co-founder, Sam Aldenton, left the company in early 2020. He sold his shares shortly before the pandemic hit the company's valuation, according to two people familiar with the matter.

The start-up has raised more than £60m in the past from other investors including Martin Lau, Tencent president, and venture capitalist Yuri Milner as well as Atomico.
